ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.

I'd recommend it. You'll learn a lot about what scholars think of the Enlightenment, how it's been interpreted, and how people in the modern academy think about it today (not always positively, and in strange ways).

A mix of intellectual and cultural historical approaches to the Enlightenment, with some key primary texts mixed in. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in the period, but especially to those preparing to for orals fields in this subject or an adjacent area.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This course deepened my knowledge of the historiography of the Enlightenment, especially since I hadn't read very deeply into it. I'm an undergraduate, so I can't speak to my dissertation and my research. But the class is a swift, sweeping overview of Enlightenment history and historiography, and in that sense it is quite useful to historians of the early modern period and such.

Yes! I came in knowing very little, and despite my inexperience with the primary sources, I left feeling as though I had a strong sense of its historical treatment over time. It likely won't contribute directly to my dissertation, but i do believe it will be extremely useful for orals.
